University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Huzhou 313001, Zhejiang, China * Corresponding author # Corresponding author To optimize the electronic structure of photocatalyst, a facile one-step approach is developed for the simultaneous realization of Zn-doping and surface oxygen vacancies (SOVs) formation on SnO2. The Zn-doped SnO2 with abundant SOVs exhibits efficient and stable performance for photocatalytic degradation of toluene under both low and high relative humidity. Experimental and theoretical calculations results show that the synergistic effects of Zn-doping and SOVs on SnO2 can considerably boost the charge transfer and separation efficiency. Utilizing the in situ DRIFTS and theoretical calculations methods, it is revealed that the benzene ring of toluene is opened at benzoic acid on the SnO2 surface and selectively at benzaldehyde on the Zn-doped SnO2 surface. This implies that Zn-doped SnO2 photocatalysts shorten the pathway of toluene degradation, and toxic intermediates can be significantly inhibited. This work could provide a promising and sustainable route for safe and efficient removal of aromatic VOCs with photocatalytic technology. Graphical Abstract The synergistic effects of Zn-doping and surface oxygen vacancies on SnO2 can boost the charge transfer and reactants activation, shorten the pathway of toluene degradation, and significantly inhibit the toxic intermediates formation. Keywords Photocatalysis Zn-doping Surface oxygen vacancies Toluene In situ FT-IR 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emitted from interior furniture and industrial activities are typical air pollutants that pose a serious threat to the environmental and human well-being [1]. Conventional technologies, including membrane separation, incineration, adsorption, and biodegradation, have been applied to remove VOCs [2]. Nevertheless, there are some potential drawbacks to these methods, such as inefficient removal, high energy cost, or secondary contamination [3]. Photocatalytic oxidation provides a mild technology for the complete mineralization of VOCs to H2O and CO2 [4,5]. It has significant potential to be an alternative to current air handling technologies. However, the widely used TiO2-based photocatalysts for degradation of VOCs still suffer from low photocatalytic conversion rate and rapid deactivation, especially for the aromatic hydrocarbons [6,7]. Therefore, it is imperative to exploit novel photocatalysts to degrade VOCs with persistent stability for the practical application. Recently, SnO2 has received more and more attention for its non-toxic, reliable stability, and excellent photoelectric performance [8,9], making the SnO2 exhibit broad application prospects in photodetectors [10], gas sensors [11], dye-sensitized solar cells [12], lithium rechargeable batteries [13], and photocatalysis [14], etc. Besides, recent studies have further reported that SnO2 is sensitive to multiple noxious gases with promising utilization prospects in gas detectors [15,16]. However, only a minority of research has investigated the potentiality of SnO2 as photocatalysts ascribed to its wide bandgap (E g = 3.6 eV) and high electron-hole pairs recombination rate, which limit its photocatalytic application [17]. In order to increase the photocatalytic efficiency, doping of metal ions and non-metal ions [18,19], surface sensitization of noble metals [20], co-doping [21,22], hybridization with carbon materials [23,24], and other methods are proposed. Transition metal ion doping often attempts to delay the rapid recombination of e–-h+ pairs by providing a defective state [25–27], The defect sites can trap photogenerated electrons or holes, thereby inhibiting recombination and facilitating interfacial charge transfer. Compared to other metal elements, the SnO2 lattice can be easily doped with Zn ions, since the Zn2+ and Sn4+ ions have a similar ionic radius of 0.73 and 0.71 Å, respectively. Replacing Sn4+ ions with Zn2+ ions would lead to surface modification, forming more oxygen vacancies to compensate for the positive charge. Most importantly, many research results have verified that the presence of SOVs not only generates the defect level but also promotes a large number of localized electrons accumulated in oxygen vacancies [28–30]. The surface oxygen vacancies (SOVs) are natural active sites for enhanced chemisorption of O2 and H2O [31–33]. The synergistic SOVs and Zn-doping construction on SnO2 can remarkably compensate for the drawback of a single exogenous ion doping or oxygen vacancy generation [34–37]. For example, ultrathin TiO2 nanosheets rich in oxygen vacancies were reported by Zhao et al. [38] using a simple copper-doping strategy, and these photocatalysts exhibited significant performance in photocatalytic reduction of N2 to NH3. Nevertheless, to our knowledge, the synergistic effects of simultaneous Zn-doping and SOVs construction on the electronic structure of SnO2 and their influence on the photocatalytic VOCs degradation have not been revealed. A hydrothermal approach was developed to realize the Zn-doping mediated formation of SOVs on SnO2 in one single process in this work. It is observed that Zn-doped SnO2 with abundant SOVs exhibits very predominant performance for the degradation of toluene in air, far exceeding that of commercial P25 photocatalyst. The synergistic effects of simultaneous Zn-doping and SOVs construction on the electronic structure of SnO2 are investigated deeply. In addition, in the process of photocatalytic degradation of toluene, some toxic intermediates such as epoxy compounds, polyols, peroxides, and aromatic oxides are produced [39]. In order to investigate the differences between the ring-opening mechanisms of Zn-doped SnO2 and pure SnO2, the ring-opening efficiencies and reaction paths of the ring-opening intermediates are provided on the basis of the theoretical calculations and in situ DRIFTS. Through this work, novel insights can be gained into the construction of novel photocatalysts via metal doping and formation of SOVs for safe and efficient removal of air pollutants. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of photocatalysts A hydrothermal approach was used to synthesize Zn-doped SnO2 samples. SnCl4·5H2O (10 mmol) and NaOH (50 mmol) were dissolved in 50 mL of deionized water, respectively, and then stirred for 20 min. Before the mixing of two solutions, the different molar mass of ZnCl2 (mol Zn/mol Sn = 10, 25, 30) was used as the source of zinc incorporated into the SnCl4 solution. Stirred the mixture for 30 min and then dropped 50 mL of ethanol solution. Subsequently, the resulting mixture was poured into the Teflon-lined stainless autoclave and kept at 180 °C for 24 h. The products were collected by centrifugation and repeatedly washed with ultra-pure water and then absolute ethanol. Finally, the products were dried at 60 °C. The obtained SnO2 with different zinc content is recorded as X-Zn-SnO2 (X = 1, 2, 3). The pure SnO2 was also synthesized in the same way without adding a zinc source. 2.2 Characterization Following those characterizations, such as X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), UV-vis reflectance spectrometry spectrum (UV-vis DRS) and electron spin resonance (ESR) measurements were used to analyze the as-obtained catalysts. Different characterizations are described in detail in Supplementary Material. 2.3 Theoretical calculations Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed with the “Vienna ab initio simulation package” (VASP 5.4.1). A plane-wave basis set with cutoff energy 400 eV was employed to ensure accurate results. K points in the Brillouin zone was sampled with a 3 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst Pack grid. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange correlation functional was conducted to model SnO2 and Zn2+ doped SnO2 with oxygen vacancy. The geometrical relaxation was performed until the residual force was not more than 0.03 eV/Å, then electronic properties were carried out. The model construction process and schematic (Figs. S(1,2)) are given in the form of Supplementary Material. 2.4 In situ DRIFTS study on the photocatalytic toluene oxidation process Continuous in situ DRIFTS system was performed using a Tensor II FT-IR spectrometer (Bruker) setup with an in-situ diffuse reflectance cell (Harrick). The experimental conditions were given in the form of Supplementary Material. 2.5 Evaluation of UV-light photocatalytic activity The photocatalytic activity of the catalysts was performed in a home-made rectangular aluminum reactor with an online photoacoustic multi-gas analyzer (GASERA ONE, USA). At first, a 0.40 g prepared sample was evenly dispersed in four frosted glasses (40 mm × 100 mm) with a small amount of ethanol. Then the glasses were dried at 60 °C until dry. The coated glass was put into the reactor (340 mL, 200 mm × 100 mm × 17 mm). The initial concentration of the continuous stream of toluene was diluted to about 45 ppm with two separated air streams (wet air and dry air). The two relative humidity (RH) levels (50% and 100%) in the reactor chamber are achieved via flow controllers. The Supplementary Material gives the efficiency calculations and reaction conditions for photocatalytic toluene. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Materials and structures The crystalline structure and phase purity are firstly investigated by XRD. The XRD pattern (Fig. 1(a) ) could correspond to the tetragonal phase SnO2 (JCPDS No. 41–1445). The crystalline characteristic peaks of ZnO, Zn2SnO4, ZnSnO3, and other impurities are not seen in the pattern. Besides, the angle of diffraction peaks did not deviate after the Zn-doping, which may be attributed to the reason that the radius of the Zn2+ ions (0.73 A) is close to that of the Sn4+ ions (0.71 A). In addition, the decreased degree of crystallinity can be observed with increasing Zn dopant concentration, attributing to the potential formation of the defect. The EPR spectra (Fig. 1(b)) show an EPR signal at g = 2.002, corresponding to oxygen vacancies [40]. The pure SnO2 shows only a weak EPR signal, suggesting the existence of intrinsic SOVs. However, the signal intensity of Zn-SnO2 was almost 2-fold enhanced compared to that of pure SnO2, indicating an elevated concentration of SOVs. An energy level below the CB can be produced by SOVs, thus enhancing light absorption and reduced e–-h+ pairs recombination [41]. Moreover, the broadening of the peak width manifests that the crystalline size of SnO2 nanoparticles is decreased [38]. Fig. S3 shows the SEM morphology of the samples. The size of average particles for SnO2 sample is 160–200 nm, while 2-Zn-SnO2 nanoparticles are composed of fine spherical nanoparticles in a smaller size range of 12–14 nm (Fig. S4). The samples size follows the sequence: 3-Zn-SnO2 < 2-Zn-SnO2 < 1-Zn-SnO2 ≪ SnO2. The particle size of Zn-doped SnO2 was significantly reduced since the Zn-doping can effectively inhibit the crystal growth and phase transition of SnO2 nanoparticles, resulting in increased content of SOVs [42]. The decrease in size is conducive to increasing its specific surface area (Table S1) and improving its active adsorption sites [43]. Fig. 2 shows the TEM and HRTEM results for SnO2 (Figs. 2(a,b)) and Zn-doped SnO2 (Figs. 2(c,d)). The micrographs also demonstrate that the formed nanoparticles are homogeneous, and aggregate to form large-sized aggregates with good dispersion. Moreover, the pure SnO2 exhibits nanoparticles with clear crystal lattices and edges, while the edges of the 2-Zn-SnO2 nanoparticles show a disordered state, indicating that the surface structure of the 2-Zn-SnO2 sample is disrupted and may form SOVs [44–48]. Both SnO2 and 2-Zn-SnO2 have lattice fringes of 0.335 nm and are attributed to (110) facets. The even distribution of Sn, O, and Zn in the nanoparticles is confirmed by the EDX element mapping of 2-Zn-SnO2 samples (Figs. 2(e−g)), suggesting the incorporation of Zn ions into SnO2 successfully. The chemical states of undoped and doped system nanoparticles were explored via XPS analysis. The survey scan (Fig. 3(a) ) displays the 2-Zn-SnO2 is mainly composed of Sn, O, Zn, and C. The binding energies of the Sn element are 486.5 and 495.0 eV (Fig. 3(b)), assigned to Sn 3d 5/2 and Sn 3d 3/2, respectively [49]. Of these, the former has a relatively lower value, attributing to the fact that SOVs reduce the binding energy of Sn [50]. The spectrum of O 1s in the Zn-doped SnO2 sample (Fig. 3(c)) shows an additional shoulder compared with the pure SnO2. The coordination of oxygen in Sn-O-Sn at 530.5 eV decreases in value with the presence of SOVs [51], the other peak at 531.7 eV corresponds to the coordination of Sn-O-Zn [52]. The binding energies at 1021.6 and 1044.7 eV correspond to Zn 2p 3/2 and Zn 2p 1/2, respectively, in the Zn 2p spectrum (Fig. 3(d)) [49]. Apparently, Zn2+ ions are doped into the SnO2 lattice and SOVs are generated simultaneously. 3.2 Optical properties and band structure Photocatalytic activity is directly affected by efficient light absorption and charge separation [53]. The light absorption properties of Zn-doped SnO2 and undoped samples were investigated by UV-vis (Fig. 4(a) ). Notably, the absorption edges of the Zn-doped SnO2 sample red shifted from 320 to 375 nm under the synergistic effects of Zn-doping and SOVs [54]. Fig. 4(a) (inset) shows the bandgap values of 3.65 and 3.32 eV for pure SnO2 and Zn-doped SnO2, respectively. The lower bandgap suggests that Zn-doping and the formation of SOVs have a substantial influence on narrowing the bandgap of SnO2. The narrowed bandgap allows SnO2 to enhance light absorption and has a superior photocatalytic activity against toluene degradation in UV light. 3.3 Photocatalytic performance, ROS generation, and transformation The efficiency of photocatalytic degradation toluene over pure SnO2 and Zn-doped SnO2 samples was evaluated under UV light (360 nm) irradiation. Fig. 4(b) shows that all the Zn-doped SnO2 samples exhibit enhanced photocatalytic efficiency, which is superior to that of pure SnO2. It demonstrates that doping with Zn2+ ions is a valuable approach for promoting the photocatalytic activity of SnO2. Furthermore, the photocatalytic performance of 2-Zn-SnO2 was tested for 35 min, and the maximum degradation rate of toluene reached 77.5% (RH = 50%). However, the photocatalytic performance of 3-Zn-SnO2 is inferior to that of 2-Zn-SnO2 due to its weak light-harvesting capability and high electron-hole pairs recombination efficiency. From Fig. 4(a), it can be seen that the light absorption intensity of 3-Zn-SnO2 is weaker than that of 2-Zn-SnO2. Fig. S5(a) shows that 3-Zn-SnO2 exhibits a higher electron-hole pairs recombination efficiency. Figs. 4(c,d) show the performance of different photocatalysts at two RH levels for recycled runs (50% and 100%), respectively. The 2-Zn-SnO2 photocatalyst remains extremely stable degradation efficiency at RH = 50% even after the fourth run, and outperforms RH = 100% owing to the competitative adsorption of H2O under high RH. Pure SnO2 also shows stable performance, but the degradation efficiency was not as efficient as 2-Zn-SnO2. In addition, the degradation of toluene in a blank experiment without a photocatalyst was 9.60%, as shown in Fig. S5(b), which may be due to the toluene oxidation by generated ozone under UV light irradiation [55]. However, P25, as a commercial catalyst, fleetly lost its catalytic activity after four cycle tests. Those results imply that 2-Zn-SnO2 is an efficient and stable photocatalyst. Doping of SnO2 with Zn2+ significantly improves the efficiency of toluene degradation, and the main reasons for this enhanced activity are the doping of Zn2+ and the formation of SOVs. The premise of heterogeneous catalysis is to fully promote the adsorption of reactants to guarantee the following photocatalytic reaction proceeds. The SOVs can provide unsaturated sites and promote adsorption and activation of the species in the reaction. The generation and transformation of reactive oxygen species (ROS: •O2 −, 1O2, and •OH−) on SnO2 and 2-Zn-SnO2 were further investigated. The electron-trapping ESR spectra are shown in Fig. 5(a) , showing the rapid depletion of electron sacrificial agent in 2-Zn-SnO2 under light conditions. The results reveal that more electrons are generated on 2-Zn-SnO2, which is in favor of upgrading the photocatalytic activity. As expected, 2-Zn-SnO2 produced more •O2 − (O2 + e− → •O2 −) than SnO2 and P25 (Fig. 5(b)), intimately related to the fact that the separated photogenerated electrons readily associate with O2 to produce more •O2 − under UV light. Meanwhile, the amount of •OH− (OH− + h+ → •OH−) produced by 2-Zn-SnO2 significantly exceeds that produced by SnO2 and P25 (Fig. 5(c)), due to the increased charge separation and H2O molecules activation. Obviously, the 1O2 yielded by the •O2 − + h+ → 1O2 pathway is stronger than those of pure SnO2 and P25. These improvements in radical production are owing to the synergistic effects of SOVs and Zn-doping on SnO2 to significantly improve photogenerated charge transfer and separation efficiency. The chemisorption and activation mechanisms of SOVs enhanced O2 and H2O were simulated by DFT calculations. The structure of the adsorbed O2 and H2O molecules were first optimized for SnO2 and Zn-doped SnO2, respectively (Figs. 6(a−d) ). Intuitively, the O–O bond length of O2 is enlarged, and the O–H–O bond angle of the H2O molecule decreases compared to the pure SnO2. Furthermore, both O2 and H2O molecules possess higher adsorption energy (E ads) on the Zn-doped SnO2 surface than that of SnO2. At the same time, the electron localization function (ELF) diagrams (Figs. 6(e−h)) also show that O2 and H2O are more likely to form electron transfer channels with atoms on the X-Zn-SnO2 surface, which facilitates the transfer of electrons. The total charge (Δq) values of −0.56 and –0.85 e for O2 correspond to the undoped and Zn-doped SnO2 samples, respectively. Δq is expressed as a negative value when electrons are transferred to the adsorbed O2. The more negative value of Δq is, the more electrons could be accepted by the adsorbed O2. Those consequences imply that the presence of SOVs weakens the O–O and H–O bonds, thereby promoting the activation of O2 and H2O to oxidize toluene. For SnO2, a shallow donor state below the CB can be formed by Zn2+ dopants [56]. Moreover, removing an O atom from the surface will cause one or two electrons to be trapped in the oxygen vacancy site. These trapped electrons can also generate donor states below the CB [57,58]. These donor states can directly affect the electronic structure of SnO2 by overlapping the CB, thereby narrowing the bandgap and shifting the Fermi level of SnO2 towards higher energy [59]. The higher Femi level can effectively facilitate the separation and transfer of photogenerated charges. Besides, the SOVs can serve not only as photo-generated charges traps but also as adsorption sites. The SOVs can enhance the adsorption of oxygen, water, and toluene. As a result, the carriers can react rapidly with these adsorbates, thus preventing the recombination of charges and increasing the generation of active radicals. In general, all mentioned above revealed that the synergistic effects of SOVs and Zn-doping could potentially improve the photogenerated charges transfer and separation efficiency, which are the critical factors to improve the photocatalytic degradation performance of toluene. 3.4 In situ DRIFTS investigation on the mechanisms of photocatalytic toluene oxidation In the photocatalytic degradation of toluene, the ring-opening process is a key step in determining the rate. The adsorption and activation of toluene molecular are the critical steps before the ring-opening. The value of –0.63 and –0.54 eV are the adsorption energy of toluene on Zn-doped SnO2 and SnO2, respectively (Figs. S6(a,b)). The ELF diagrams (Figs. S6(c,d)) demonstrate that the adsorbed toluene molecule is more likely to form electron channels with the Zn-doped SnO2 surface, which is conducive to electron transport. The Δq values of +0.002 and +0.011 e for toluene correspond to SnO2 and Zn-doped SnO2 samples, respectively. Δq is expressed as a positive value when electrons are donated to the electron-deficient field. Thus, the more positive of the Δq is, the easier of the toluene molecules are oxidized to a higher valence, which further facilitating the conduct of photocatalytic oxidation. The oxidation route of toluene before ring-opening is as follows: toluene → benzyl alcohol → benzaldehyde → benzoic acid. The in situ DRIFTS monitoring of intermediates and products during toluene oxidation was carried out. Table S2 lists the assignments of the IR bands. Under the dark conditions, it can be observed that many new bands show up after 20 min of the toluene injection (Figs. 7(a,c) ). On the SnO2 surface, the spectral band at 3635 cm−1 is benzyl alcohol and 1357 cm−1 is benzaldehyde. The band at 1628 cm−1 is due to the adsorbed OH groups. For 2-Zn-SnO2, an increase in intermediates was observed, including benzyl alcohol (3631 cm−1), benzaldehyde (1454 and 1298 cm−1), and benzoic acid (1493 cm−1). The bands of 3028 and 1357 cm−1 are attributed to the benzene ring, indicating that it cannot be opened in the absence of light. Furthermore, the normalized species evolution results (Fig. 7(e)) based on IR spectra in time sequence showed that the accumulation of benzyl alcohol and benzaldehyde on 2-Zn-SnO2 was significantly higher than that of SnO2. Figs. 7(b,d) show the in situ DRIFTS spectra of photocatalytic toluene oxidation of undoped and doped SnO2 surfaces under UV irradiation, respectively. The peaks of toluene and benzoyl alcohol in the reaction process of 2-Zn-SnO2 and SnO2 were decreased compared with the adsorption process, which indicated that they were converted to benzaldehyde (1699, 1608, 1393, 1216, 1693, 1599, and 1304 cm−1) and benzoic acid (1504 and 1401 cm−1). From the normalized species evolution (Fig. 7(f)) of the reaction, it can be seen that benzoic acid was oxidized from toluene and accumulated on the surface of SnO2. The unsaturated long-chain enol gradually broke off after benzene ring opening and were eventually oxidized to CO2 and H2O. However, on the surface of Zn-doped SnO2, the benzyl alcohol consumption was evident, and the benzaldehyde accumulation was significant. In addition, benzoic acid did not change significantly over time, and this experiment confirmed that the ring-opening process on Zn-doped SnO2 primarily begins with benzaldehyde. The results above indicate that the benzene ring is likely to open on the SnO2 surface at benzoic acid and selectively at benzaldehyde on the Zn-doped SnO2 surface, thereby shortening the degradation pathway of toluene and significantly suppressing the intermediates. The normalized absorbance of the final mineralized product CO2 over time is a visual indication of the degradation efficiency. The diagram in Fig. S7 shows that more CO2 is produced on the surface of 2-Zn-SnO2 than that of SnO2, which not only confirms that Zn-doping and creation of oxygen vacancies substantially inhibit the production of toxic intermediates, but also indicates that toluene can be made to degrade more efficiently. The DFT calculations revealed the potential mechanism of the difference in reaction selectivity between the Zn-doped SnO2 and SnO2. Fig. 8 showed that the adsorption energy of the Zn-doped SnO2 to that aromatic-ring containing species increased obviously in contrast to SnO2, indicating that the charge transfer between the adsorbents and Zn-doped SnO2 promoted the oxidation of benzyl. In particular, the Eads pattern of benzaldehyde and benzoic acid is reversed between the Zn-doped SnO2 and SnO2, which may manifest that benzaldehyde is more favorable converted on SnO2 and decomposed on Zn-doped SnO2, thus effectively shortening the degradation path of toluene [5]. The photocatalytic toluene degradation process on the surface of SnO2 photocatalyst with Zn-doping and SOVs are illustrated in Fig. 9 . 4 Conclusions We have implemented the simultaneous Zn-doping and SOVs generation on SnO2 using a simple one-step method. These Zn-doped SnO2 nanoparticles with abundant SOVs exhibited efficient and stable performance for the photocatalytic degradation of toluene under both low and high RH conditions. The donor states of Zn-doping and SOVs can can overlap the CB and thus directly affect the electronic structure of SnO2, thereby narrowing the bandgap and shifting the Fermi level of SnO2 toward high energy level. The SOVs can act as adsorption sites to facilitate the chemisorption of H2O and O2. The synergistic effects of SOVs and Zn-doping on SnO2 can dramatically boost the charge separation and transfer efficiency, which remarkably improved the activity of toluene degradation. Moreover, the benzene ring is likely to be opened on the SnO2 surface at benzoic acid, whereas on the Zn-doped SnO2 surface, the benzene ring is selectively opened at benzaldehyde. Hence, the degradation pathway of toluene is shortened, and toxic intermediates can be significantly inhibited. Some new insights and awareness can be offered through this work on the construction of novel photocatalysts via combining metal doping and the oxygen vacancies generation for safe and efficient removal of air pollutants. coredata.dc:description: To optimize the electronic structure of photocatalyst, a facile one-step approach is developed for the simultaneous realization of Zn-doping and surface oxygen vacancies (SOVs) formation on SnO2. The Zn-doped SnO2 with abundant SOVs exhibits efficient and stable performance for photocatalytic degradation of toluene under both low and high relative humidity. Experimental and theoretical calculations results show that the synergistic effects of Zn-doping and SOVs on SnO2 can considerably boost the charge transfer and separation efficiency. Utilizing the in situ DRIFTS and theoretical calculations methods, it is revealed that the benzene ring of toluene is opened at benzoic acid on the SnO2 surface and selectively at benzaldehyde on the Zn-doped SnO2 surface. This implies that Zn-doped SnO2 photocatalysts shorten the pathway of toluene degradation, and toxic intermediates can be significantly inhibited. This work could provide a promising and sustainable route for safe and efficient removal of aromatic VOCs with photocatalytic technology.

coredata.dc:title: Zn-doping mediated formation of oxygen vacancies in SnO2 with unique electronic structure for efficient and stable photocatalytic toluene degradation
